reviewText: This movie is set in 1960s Jackson, Mississippi and tells the story of an aspiring young Southern journalist who wants to tell what it is like to work as a housemaid/domestic helper from the black woman's perspective. Skeeter, whose friends are busy spending their days in a privileged world of playing bridge, serving in the Junior League, and entertaining, wants nothing more than to gain experience as a writer so she can go to New York and work for a large publishing company. Skeeter's friends are married and living in their perfect world of owning the right house, in the right neighborhood, having babies, and depending on their black maids to do the work of raising their children, cleaning their homes, doing their shopping and cooking their meals. Skeeter doesn't date or have a boyfriend; her goal is to become a writer, which is an embarrassment to her mother, and scandalous to her friends. Despite the times, Skeeter has a deep sense of how wrong the blacks are treated and she is both liked and respected by those who work for her own family as well as those who work for her friends. This is not the case with the snobby Miss Hilly and Miss Elizabeth, who both view their maids as less than human because they are black. Miss Hilly draws up an initiative to require all households who employ black help to build a special toilet for them because "they carry different diseases from us". This was a time when blacks were prohibited from using the same public toilets as whites, and were also forbidden from drinking from the same water fountain, as well as many other discriminatory practices that made Mississippi such a shameful bastion of racial segregation and discrimination.Aibileen and Minnie are the two maids that work for Miss Elizabeth and Miss Hilly, and are best friends who share their personal sorrows with each other. After Miss Hilly catches Minnie in her bathroom during a violent thunderstorm that prevents her from going outside to use the toilet, she fires Minnie and spreads lies that will insure Minnie is unable to find employment anywhere else in town. Aibileen tells Minnie that Celia Foote, an outcast from Hilly's social circle, and the woman who is married to Hilly's past boyfriend, is looking for help. Minnie, desperate for a job to support her children, swallows her pride and goes to work for Celia. It turns out Celia lives in a huge old mansion that her husband's family have owned for generations. She is a simple and sweet girl raised on the wrong side of the tracks who wants nothing more than to find a place in the world her husband was born into. She accepts Minnie as an equal, something that immediately raises Minnie's suspicions because of the prevailing racial prejudices in the Deep South against blacks. Both of them being outcasts from the circle of the Miss Hilly's world, and with reputations that are tarnished by Miss Hilly, they forge a bond slowly that will benefit them both in unique ways.Aibileen is approached by Skeeter to tell what it is like to work as a maid and, although at first resistant to the idea, she reluctantly begins to open up about the things she has experienced over many years working in the homes of white women and raising their children. It is a dangerous thing for both Skeeter and Aibileen in the climate of racial prejudice that exists, and they must keep their project secret. Skeeter has promised that she will never use Aibileen's real name, nor her own as the writer, and encourages Aibileen to see if Minnie might be willing to also tell of her perspective as to what it has been like to work as a maid for white families. Minnie is bitter over what she has suffered at the hands of the cruel Hilly, and grudgingly agrees to share as long as her name isn't used. Before long their trust in Skeeter and the years of resentment they have felt over their treatment leads Aibileen and Minnie to give up the secrets of the white women of Jackson as Skeeter sympathetically listens and pens their stories for a book titled "The Help".Minnie's desire to get revenge on Hilly leads her to carry out an act she calls "the terrible awful", something that is so outrageous that she is ashamed to ever tell anyone what she has done. It also is hilarious, and Hilly's slightly senile and forgetful mother witnesses it and laughs uproariously at Minnie's revenge, but this leads Hilly to put her mother in a nursing home because she is afraid she will tell everyone in town what happened and make her the laughing stock of Jackson. Eventually when racial tensions and injustices, including the murder of Medgar Evers, lead to the brutal treatment of one of the maids in Jackson, it serves as the catalyst that encourages the other maids of Jackson to open up to Skeeter about the way they have been treated over the years while working for white families, and they agree to spill their secrets, some of which are terribly sad, some of which are bittersweet, some of which are hilarious, and some of which are damning for the white families. Minnie tells Aibileen about "the terrible awful" she did to Miss Hilly and each maid knows that they have "insurance" to protect them since Miss Hilly would never let anyone believe the stories are set in Jackson once they are published, because Minnie's story of "the terrible awful", which is included in the many stories that will come to be told in "The Help", would make Hilly the joke of Jackson if anyone ever knew what Minnie did to her. As their stories are written, Skeeter prepares to include her own story of Constantine, the black maid who raised her from infancy, and how Skeeter's mother betrayed the loyalty and love Constantine had for the Phelan family, especially for Skeeter.Once finished and sent off to the publishing house in New York, the manuscript is hastily published to coincide with Dr. Martin Luther King's march on Washington, something that will bring the civil rights movement to the forefront of America as the struggle for racial equality tears at the fabric of the Old South, revealing the humiliating treatment of blacks which has been kept largely untold in other parts of the country.Skeeter's book comes at a time ripe for the telling. Once it hits stores in Jackson, everyone is buying it and wondering where the stories were originated because they seem to divulge things that fit with events among Jackson's white families although no mention is made of the author (simply "anonymous") or the town where the stories took place. As more and more interest in the book develops, Hilly buys it and when she reads about "the terrible awful" she knows Skeeter has written the book, but she tells everyone the book can't possibly be about Jackson. She confronts Skeeter about the book but Skeeter stands her ground and tells Hilly she can't prove anything, and Hilly can't - unless she wants to make herself and every other white family in her social circle look bad and expose the secrets which they had assumed would always be safe in the climate of white superiority, where the lives of their black maids could be ruined for the slightest reason. Now everything has changed and the tables have turned!Finally, Celia Foote decides to make an appearance at the annual Christmas Junior League gala so she can tell Miss Hilly that she never stole away her old boyfriend, because she believes this is why Miss Hilly hates her and has deliberately excluded her from being in the Junior League and the circle of wealthy white women that form Hilly and Elizabeth's coterie of friends. Little does she realize that she is about to make herself look like a fool among the snobby women of Jackson, even though she is married to the influential son of an old monied family. She is also about to discover that she will never be accepted, even if she tries to tell Hilly of her innocence in Hilly's breakup with Johnny. Although it makes for a sad and yet funny scene, the wheels are set in motion for everything to change as the The Help's stories circulate among Jackson's citizens and expose the terrible secrets and the injustices toward blacks that have been buried in secrecy for so longThroughout the movie are moments of extreme hilarity and moments of great sadness as the story unfolds, but the ending is one that provides redemption for Skeeter, Aibileen, Minnie, and even Celia Foote. The strength and empowerment that comes to those who have never known anything but powerlessness is the redemption, and the beginning of hope for a better life in the changing times of the civil rights movement.Having grown up as a white child in the South during the time this story takes place, I remember so vividly how racial segregation was - the signs that separated the use of public facilities for blacks and whites, as well as a time when blacks were not allowed to ride anywhere except the back of buses. It is a time that is burned into my mind and makes me deeply ashamed of the degrading treatment blacks suffered at the hands of whites. Even as a child, I remember the downcast eyes and the role of subservience that defined how blacks were expected to behave in the presence of whites. There is no exaggeration in this book as to the black experience in the Deep South. The ending of the movie was so uplifting as I'm The Living Proof is sung by Mary J. Blige! It is simply a marvelous movie. I highly recommend it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: A relatively unknown director, Tate Taylor pulls a rabbit out of the hat with this surprisingly good film.  Admittedly the film is pointed at followers of Oprah as it never overplays the police violence, the murders, and the church desecrations of the black churches.  There are incidents but they are kept off screen for the most part.  Instead the film focuses on the mental abuse of black maids working for middle class whites in 60's Jackson Mississippi.A young writer played by Emma Stone manages to get a gig writing a book about maids in the south.  She struggles to get interviews with "the help" as they do not want to jeopardize their jobs or their lives.  Eventually they give in.  I didn't live in the South during this era, but the events seem pretty authentic to me.  Black maids raise children and the children eventually grow up and become the maid's bosses or the maid's daughter's bosses as their "ownership" is passed down.  The movie at well over 2 hours moves along briskly as we continue to root for maids in their effort to highlight their lives to the rest of the country.The filmmakers do a good job differentiating between the characters.  Every white person is not evil.  Every black person isn't an angel.  Of the evil white ladies, none is more evil than Hilly, nicely played by Bryce Dallas Howard.  Celia (Jessica Chastain) on the other hand is a sympathetic girl of "white trash" origins.  While Stone has a nice scene with her mother (Allison Janney), the real stars are Viola Davis as Aibileen, the first maid to come forward and her best friend Minny (Octavia L. Spencer).  Both give Oscar-worthy performances.  I was especially taken with Ms. Spencer who gives great depth and dimension to her character.
summary: 4 1/2 stars for another excellent fim of 2011

reviewText: A forgotten look at the past that is full of a lot of emotion.  Too many movies being made that are set into the future but this one is one that takes us back into the past for some rattling realities.  Regardless if you are old enough to appreciate the history, you will still find this movie full of entertainment.  Great performances from an all star cast and to me, I really enjoyed the memories it brought back.  Although this type of racism was exclusive of the deep south state of Mississippi  where violent bigotry was the mainstream and many movies have been made about the horrors of racism in Mississippi, I have wonderful memories of our family having "help" during the 60's only it was much more of a family type relationship where they were part of our family and sat with us during meals and were part of my fondest childhood memories.  It was a time when everyone had to pull together to make ends meet when white families were so large and depended on farms and the Blacks would become extended parts of the family for their own survival as well and were never treated as less than we were.  It was just everyone helping each other as I innocently remember it and this movie brings back wonderful memories of those times.  Shame on Mississippi for their HATE and Violence and their behavior that has given life to so much animosity between the races over the decades that spilled into neighboring states.  Great Movie everyone should watch with an open mind and not to allow the sins of a few keep hatred alive.
summary: An Humbling Movie that is Full of Entertainment

reviewText: This is an excellent film depicting the way a cruel, Jewish, literary agent at Harper and Row, "Missus Stein," toys with and tortures a gifted and naive young southern woman who is trying to break in as a writer.  Even after Stein clearly recognizes the literary/commercial merit of the work, she continues her sadistic ways by making a non-negotiable demand for a full manuscript in a completely unreasonable amount of time.  The director deftly emphasizes Stein's cruelty by having her layout her demand over the phone while gaily enjoying her evening with two male companions in New York.  Her terms and her manner of presenting them underscore her pleasure in having one hundred percent of the power over the aspiring writer.  I must admit that I am somewhat surprised that Hollywood would touch this theme of the cruelty and exploitation of southerners by New York power brokers.
summary: Exposé of New York sadism and exploitation

reviewText: This flic was on sale so I thought "what the hey" for $1.99 what can I lose. This is a fantastic movie, a touching tale of the prejudice that existed in that era (and sadly still exists)in the "deep south". As a "New Yorker" (now transplanted in Georgia)I was only exposed to this once in my life, in 1962 (age 10)I traveled with an Aunt to Virginia and needed to use the boys room. There were 2 and not knowing local customs & laws I thought a "colored" bathroom would be more interesting than one that was plain "white". A local redneck dragged me out while I was still peeing and began cussing me outside. My Aunt ran up and began berating this ignorant person then explained to me the meaning of these hateful practices. This is a "MUST SEE" for all who do not remember and a great lesson for those too young. In short the best $1.99 I have spent in a long time!! A+++++

reviewText: I just watched THE HELP, and I will probably vote for it to win the Best Actor Ensemble Screen Actors Guild Award. The cast was wonderful, and it's nice to witness a true, wonderful ensemble of actresses and several of them Afro/American. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer emerge as true stars. The entire movie is very well cast with pitch-perfect performances.However, as significant as the themes and background are, some of THE HELP seems obvious, contrived, unrealistic and began to remind me of TV's DESPERATE HOUSEWIVES. Too much melodramatic sensationalism, and problems are tied up to quickly, neatly, and happily at the end. But I still highly recommend THE HELP for its originality, beautifully developed themes, vital social significance and many wonderful performances and wouldn't be disappointed if it wins several Oscars, including best movie of the year. It's one hell of a lot better than THE ARTIST, that's for sure!

reviewText: I'm sure that my subject line has been thrown around in Hollywood before, but this is a film which truely deserves such praise.  While Emma Stone has seemingly proven that she can do no wrong (for me at least), it was Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer who shined in this film which exposed both positives and negatives about the lives of "the help" in Mississippi during the Civil Rights movement.  Granted, there were more negatives, but that was to be expected.  This film is just a few steps from being considered a documentary.  While the plot may be depressing at times, it brings it's appropriate share of laughs and Miss Octavia Spencer is largely to thank for that.  I was also pleased to see Allison Janney in this picture as I've been a fan of hers since "The West Wing".  Like Ms. Stone, Miss Janney did not dissappoint as she plays a mother who's clearly dealing with the moral conflict of not being racist in Mississippi in the 1960s while dealing with her struggles against cancer.  Side note:  could I get the name of the acting coach who taught everyone their southern accents...that just made it all better.  Anyway, Viola Davis as a maternal figure who finds her oppurtunity to change what she sees as a never-ending cycle of oppression is terrific.  Miss Davis's more intraverted manners balance nicely with the outgoing nature brought by Octavia Spencer.  While Emma Stone's character traits aren't really unique or memorable except for her wanting to be judged for her mind instead of her body (i.e. she didn't major in "husband hunting" during her university years), it was these non-original, stock-character traits that fit her perfectly into the story, allowing the three leading ladies to develop the right amount of chemistry for this film.  It is a must-have if you want any picture that's interesting with a solid story that you just want to see through to the end.

reviewText: I did not read the book, so I can't comment on whether the film was faithful to the original. I watched the DVD with my best friend, who had gotten it for Christmas. It seems to be pitched as a "feel good" movie, but I didn't feel all that good after seeing it.Don't get me wrong, as story it did what story is supposed to do: emotionally engage, entertain, and portray a world of its own creation. But once the curtain came down, it left me feeling unsettled and chagrined.The positives are that the time and place are vividly envoked--so much so that I was almost surprised when I looked out my window and saw December in Pennsylvania and not Jackson in the summertime. The plot certainly does grab and hold your attention, and the acting is terrific throughout.Things that were a bit out of kilter: as someone who grew up in the sixties, I knew right away that Skeeter's hair was way wrong. Everyone, but EVERYONE in 1962 had helmet hair. No way would a girl from an upper-class Southern family be allowed to leave the house with that cloud of spirals floating around her face. Also, the women are too thin. It was the norm for a woman, even a young one, to have a little pot below her waist. Check out period clothing, and you will see that the skirts are actually cut for that type of figure.I enjoyed the story and portrayal of the maids finally opening up and telling Skeeter their stories, but I was uncomfortable with the idea that blacks could only improve their lot when a benevolent white benefactor swooped down from the sky to lift them up. However, on further reflection I think that is to a certain extent true. This was a period in which blacks were automatically completely discounted as not intelligent enough to lift themselves up, so that it did take a white person becoming involved before most whites would even notice enough to disagree. Not because blacks are by nature stupid and ineffective; but because they were simply invisible to the white world.I also was hoping Skeeter would stay in Jackson and work for Civil Rights there, but again thinking further, I realized that a woman in her position most likely would've chosen to go to New York. She would probably have believed she could do more good getting her information out to a wider--and white Northern (and therefore more influential) audience, and she would have known there was no future for her as an individual in Mississippi.So although the film ended as it probably should have, as the denoument to a story it wasn't quite satisfying. But, the film is well put together, the narrative is strong, and the portrayals are excellent. I certainly recommend it, not only as a story but as a launching pad for discussion and real thought about the past and its role in shaping a better future.
summary: A "Feel Good" Movie? Not So Sure

reviewText: I think this was a good movie but not a great movie.  While I feel that there were some great scenes and good acting, most notably  the character Minny, played by Octavia Spencer, the film really didn't measure up to the book.  The book at least had some detail and of course not all of that could be covered in a movie.  Also like a lot of books adapted to movies some of the elements are changed to make the outcome look better than it actually is, like what really happens to Skeeter's mom, played by Allison Janney.  Also I felt that most of the characters were flat--there was no dimension to them.  They were either mean spirited or kind.  Minny was the only one that showed any sort of emotion--she was outspoken, funny, and at the same time had a lot of compassion especially with her employer Celia, the "white trash" outcast who desperately needed a friend. If anyone should get an Oscar in this movie it should be Octavia Spencer.  My absolutely favorite film of the Civil Rights era was The Long Walk Home starring Sissy Spacek(Hilly's crazy mom!) and Whoopi Goldberg which deals with the Montgomery bus boycott.

reviewText: This is a remarkable film of contrasts. Not just the blatantly obvious contrasts of black and white, rich and poor, free and slave, good and evil, courage and cowardice, or between those fighting for equality and those fighting to keep others from being equal. The film does a great job in showing the considerable contrast within Christianity itself. The conflict between the compassionate, loving, understanding attitude, contrasted with the fearful, vengeful, punishing attitude, all within groups of the same religion. Although, some may argue, this is inherent in man's nature, i.e., a "Lord of the Flies" type of characteristic.The true contrast is between faith and fear, although both are basically the same, belief. For example, if you have a fear of snakes then you must believe in the ability of a snake to harm you or you would not fear it. If a shepherd cannot get his sheep to follow by faith and trust, he drives them with fear using the dogs. We see this contrast in religions that emphasize either an extreme punishment or an extreme reward. The film is remarkable in the way it demonstrates the power of both faith and fear. The oppressed stand in faith against all odds prejudicial to them and the oppressors spew fear and hate in order to subjugate them. People will either recognize faith, love and hope, or they will recognize fear and hate and will lean toward one or the other.Fear causes torment, which leads to hate. A person is driven by fear and hate and begins to recognize the familiar communal voice of fear and hate around them. This voice redirects the fear and hate against whomever or whatever it chooses. Any inhibition is removed by destroying the morals and conscience through self-righteousness and self-justification. The voice, which is the actual source of the fear, then becomes the controlling influence. Depending on the source, fair and balanced, if truthfully noted, is actually fear and bias.The thing about contrast is that you can see perspective very clearly and this film refuses to allow any gray areas. No matter how much Hilly Holbrook tries to justify her iniquitous ways by lying to others and herself, you see through it without question. The scene where Celia comes to the bridge party and Hilly has everyone hide, even though the driveway and street are filled with cars. Or the benefit she holds for hungry African children, while at the same time she subjugates, persecutes, and oppresses the same in her own household and community. Or by taking pride in her warped sense of Christian charity by helping her maid by actually not helping her. Hilly lives in self-delusion and believes her own lies and thinks she has everyone else fooled also. Curiously, it is not Hilly's character that I find the most disgusting and offensive. Racists, bigots, homophobes, hate and fear-mongers can be recognized, we see them for what they really are, controlled by fear. It's Elizabeth's character that I find the most disturbing. The level of cowardice she exhibits by being a pawn is horrible. She doesn't realize she is simply being used. Hilly does not care for Elizabeth or anyone else, she controls them through fear in order to become substantial in her own eyes and those she deceives.The films strong message shows the only path to true freedom. Only by accepting the truth can you truly be free. If you continue to lie to yourself eventually you will meet someone who refuses to acknowledge the facade. Having the courage to define yourself and refusing to allow others to tell you how you should live your life is true freedom. Freedom from fear.
summary: Walk a mile in someone else's shoes.

reviewText: This movie focuses on a community of black maids who find the courage to tell their stories -- during the beginning of the civil rights fight. The acting is superb, and the storyline is almost always excellent (there are a few exceptions that I will mention later). But first, I want to address the criticism that this film perpetuates the "mammy" stereotype.I'm not sure the critics and I were watching the same film, because, frankly, this movie didn't do that. These are not subservient, complacent, happy to do as they were bid African American maids and nannies. These were women who lived in a world where black people could be lynched, or utterly ruined, by a white person's whim. They took the jobs that were available to them -- the jobs that white people didn't want. The fact of the matter is that generations of black women filled jobs like these after the civil war -- not because they liked it, or didn't have ambitions or abilities beyond raising white people's kids, but because white people set up a system that allowed them little else. These women came across as real people -- who saw the injustice in life, but also lived in a time and place where it was literally dangerous to say or do anything about it. They were resigned, but not "mammies".I do understand that this is a sensitive issue, but I think the critics should evaluate the characters, not just the occupations those characters held. Considering the ways these women buck the system -- from the "horrible nasty" to collaborating on a book to Aibileen authoring her own books -- I would say that what these maids did were not the acts of "mammies".There were a few things I did not like about this movie. One was Aibileen's use of "You is..." I don't remember her using any such phrases anywhere in the movie except when she was talking to her young charge. Otherwise, she has an exceptional command of the English language, is very well spoken, and ends up a writer (!!); there didn't seem a need for this dialect.Secondly, there was the latrines on the lawn bit. It's a good gag, but it didn't come off as very believable that people would dump old toilets on a prize winning lawn -- especially not without checking first.I also have reservations about the "horrible nasty" (I won't mention what that was, in case you don't already know)...I can't make up my mind if it was hilarious or not, and it doesn't help that it is referenced a LOT during the movie. Deserved, yes. Too far over the line? The jury is still out.That, though, is the extent of what I thought could have been improved. Otherwise, the characters were all very well done, and the storyline very interesting (and sad!). The acting, though, is the crown jewel in this film...everyone, and I do mean everyone, did such a good job. The actresses were really the ones who made this movie. Congrats to them!5/5 stars
summary: Very good film, no perpetuation of the "mammy" stereotype as some have suggested
Title: N/A

reviewText: Overall, a good movie, that had moments of greatness.This movie is based on a book. I have not read the book so I can only speak to what ended up on the screen.The story follows two women, in a small town in Mississippi, who live on opposite sides of the tracks.  One woman is a maid and has lost her inner fire, and the other woman is trying to find herself despite the social restrictions and pressures of who she's "supposed to be".  Both women end up working together, writing a book about the lives of "The Help" in their small town, a behind the scenes look at the lives of poor black women in Mississippi.There were some absolutely great moments in this movie, some that broke your heart or even made you laugh outloud.  However, they were not as frequent as they should have been, in my opinion.  And that tells me, areas of the story were lacking. Also, I did not believe the character development of the maid was as good as it should have been.  The idea for the movie, was fantastic, but the idea needed a little more work in the writing and development department.Sometimes a good movie gets a lot of attention, partially because it's so unusual (the story) and the timing of when it came out (nothing else like it).  While that may be true, it still doesn't make it a great movie.I would buy this movie for my collection.
summary: Tea: This is a very nice blend

reviewText: in the fifties and early sixties black maids/cooks in the Deep South worked (and sort of "slaved") for rich white women in big houses for rediculously low wages. Octavia Spencer and Viola Davis are wonderful as a long suffering black cooks and  Bryce Dallas Howard is over-the-top as an exacting rich white. In this movie the black women are shown as selfless saints and most of the rich whites are selfish demons (slave drivers?). Black and white, so to speak. A white outcast journalist, (Emma Stone) writes a book about how the maids are exploited.  Jessica Costain plays another white social outcast of the vindictive BDH.Having lived through this era in the South, the blacks, as depicted in this movie, are a bit too good to be true. I understand the book was a lot more realistic and showed a lot more sarcasm and shades of gray and in the black characters.... the white women? pretty much as depicted!A very entertaining movie nevertheless, and hysterically funny in places...Be careful when you eat pie.

reviewText: I absolutely enjoyed this film.  Viola Davis carries her main character with so much grace and dignity - it is magical to see her portray a housekeeper who is also a nanny.  Story is placed in the deep south, during 1960s when civil rights movement is taking its momentum.  But like every movement, it takes time for it to reach rural areas and small towns.Emma Stone plays Skeeter, a white girl from privileged family who is not looking for husband after her college graduation; she is looking to establish herself as a journalist and writer.  She is sensitive and caring person and she her physical appearance fits perfectly for her role.  Her curly hair expresses her inner rebellion of the world around her; her big eyes communicate a much deeper emotions which are hearbreaking once she starts meeting with maids who tell her their stories from their years of service to while affluent families in town.This is a fabulous movie for every generation and both genders.  It is a reminder of time passed and it is also a humble look at strength these ordinary women had in order to server families that often humiliated them and then go back to their husbands who often treated them no better.

reviewText: This is without a doubt the best film released in 2011...my opinion of course.  The message of this film and its historic significance tip the scales in its favor. It is the first film I've been to in a very long time where the theater audience stood and applauded at the end. Some may say this is just a "guilty white folks film", but having grown up in the South and having come of age (I graduated from high school in 1963) during the era in which this film is set, I can relate to much of the story. It is authentic in its telling of the relationship between white families, especially wealthy white families, and their "Help". I say that from a white perspective; but I suspect the same is true for blacks who matured during that era. This story though is not heavy handed; it is balanced with just the right amount of pathos and humor; you will be laughing out loud one minute and reaching for a tissue the next. Hard to believe this is the first directorial effort for Tate Taylor, as he has crafted a masterful work here. The casting too is perfect. Viola Davis, who we don't see much on the big screen, shows why she is such a highly regarded stage actress with her portrayal of the maid, Aibileen Clark. Octavia Spencer delivers a superlative performance too, as Minny Jackson. Emma Stone, in what I believe is her best performance, plays the lead, Skeeter Phelan, an aspiring young writer, who coaxes the stories from the "help" for her book, appropriately titled "The Help". Also look for Bryce Dallas Howard (Ron Howard's daughter) Allison Janney, Cicely Tyson and Sissy Spacek in fine performances. This film will help us remember when we talk about "the good old days" that some things were definitely not so good.

reviewText: Again, we have many reviewers that just can't get away from comparing the film to the book. That has always seemed unfair to me, and is always annoying. Director Tate Taylor has assembled a dedicated, focused cast, and has presented a tale of fiction that may be pretty much like it was. To get away from the mundane lot of the abused Black maids, we have a white character, the sweet and clueless Celia, played to perfection by Jessica Chastain, whose inclusion just adds to the nastiness of the white female antagonists.Most males might be put off by this film, which has no major male characters and is purely from a female perspective. The book, too, was most popular with females. The bottom line is that this is a film with heart and integrity, an earnest attempt to present a riveting narrative. The acting is excellent, without exception. Viola Davis is fine as the central character, though she never really has a big "scene", but consistent in her sad demeanor, on a road to nothingness. Emma Stone is fine as Skeeter, the real protagonist; Bryce Dallas Howard is wonderfully nasty; Sissy Spacek is wonderfully spunky; the great Cecily Tyson has a too brief appearance, an important character, Skeeter's true inspiration. Allison Janney, too, is like an older version of Howard's. Octavia Spencer's Minny is feisty and fun, sweet and sad, the whole nine yards.But it's Jessica Chastain's Celia that is so fully formed, presenting practically every emotion available to an actress. Though from the "wrong side of the tracks", she's not stupid. She's definitely a fish out of water, is treated with contempt and ridicule, is truly devoted to her husband, makes light of regular disappointments, and is ready to give up until she meets Minny. I won't blab away the plot, but a particular scene where Minny comes to her rescue is one of the most heart-wrenching scenes I can recall, handled by 2 very capable actresses.I enjoyed "The Help" very much. The innate goodness of people is well explored, as well as the conditioned, ignorant meanness of others. A good lesson in how to treat your fellow human being. Despite the ugliness that occurs, it's really a joyous film. Unfortunately, ALL the stories may never be known, and, I'm sure, weren't as positive. Highly recommended.
summary: The haters,.the hated, and the marginally dismissed...

reviewText: The Help(released  Aug./11)is a thoroughly disappointing entry in a long line of film entries to do with race relations in the south;this particular foray finding us in the early 60s.One Skeeter Phelan(Emma Stone) is an aspiring writer who gains a toehold into her profession by writing an advice column for the Jackson,Miss.newspaper.Upon returning home she finds the black maid that raised her has been dismissed.She is upset and gets a brainwave to write a book from the titled "helps" perspective.We are introduced to various maids,their families and their hardships in relation to their working circumstances,along with their social ones.We are also given almost a verbatim accounting of the then laws of the State of Mississippi governing Blacks and their interactions with Whites and visa versa.Many people get hurt along the way,both white and black,both mentally and physically.Skeeter,of course in the end,gets Stein books in NYC to finally publish her "heartrending"(my quotes)story.Yahoo.From the moment a movie begins I want to feel that 1)it is actually going somewhere,which will and most importantly, 2)get me involved,somewhere along the line,in what I am seeing on the screen.Neither of these things occurred to any degree whatsoever during this ponderous 146 minute borefest supremo.When the movie tried to get interesting at various points I was so put off with what had led up to that point,that I could have cared less.And to make matters worse the plot and dialogue were cliched to the nth degree.Sorry folks we have been there and done this SO many times that a film of this topic,in this day and age,absolutely HAS to be top drawer from the start or it is doomed to failure,because it has found far superior platforms in the past either at the movies or on television.The best thing I can say about this film is it was really good to see Cicely Tyson,Sissy Spacek and Mary Steenburgen back on the screen.Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r and the picture is clean and crisp.Extras include commentary and deleted scenes.In conclusion give this bomb a wide pass.If you want something more stimulating and decent about race relations and prejudice in the south,this is NOT the place to look.
summary: Another race relations flick...but NOT done well at all

reviewText: <strong>The Help</strong> (Tate Taylor, 2011)By any technical metric you would care to name, <em>The Help</em> is an unqualified success. Writer/director Tate Taylor, normally an actor (<em>Winter's Bone</em>), hit one out of the park in almost every imaginable way with this movie, only his second full-length feature behind the camera. Every cast member is excellent in his or her role, and a roster of solid performers all bring their A games to the table. The script is warm, funny (which I did not expect at all), and exceptionally well-paced. The cinematography is very pretty, if conventional. Even the soundtrack is manipulative without being too obtrusive (Thomas Newman > John Williams, but then these days everyone > John Williams). In other words, as a surface feature, or looked at as an entirely separate phenomenon than the book, <em>The Help</em> is an unqualified success, one that deserves every bit of its hype and the almost-in-the-top-250 rating it has on IMDB as I write this.On the other hand, Hollywood, we need to sit down and have a talk about two phenomena prominently on display in this movie that have pissed a whole lot of people off. I'm not sure I'm the right person to have this talk with you, Hollywood, since I'm a white, almost-middle-aged male writing from a position of (at least relative) privilege. But you don't listen when black folks talk about it, even the black folks you seem to be so fond of. Maybe it'll sound different coming from someone else.First off: let's talk a little about the Magical Negro. (Those of you not reading this on Amazon who have never heard the term can find out a great deal more about it on wikipedia: [link removed for Amazon consumption].) What's up with that? Are we somehow incapable of mixing races in a mainstream Hollywood film without adding a Magical Negro trope? (The last film I remember that did so successfully was Wes Craven's <em>The Serpent and the Rainbow</em> twenty-five years ago.) While there can be no doubting that Constantine (played here by the great Cicely Tyson--coincidentally, aunt to Cathy Tyson, who was so distinctly non-magical in <em>The Serpent and the Rainbow</em>) fits the trope to a T, did you really have to go our of your way to hit every signpost? Couldn't you have made her, you know, a real, flesh-and-blood character? I realize that a superhuman ideal is great for tugging on the heartstrings when the inevitable confrontation occurs (we know from the movie's first five minutes that something has happened to Constantine, we just don't know what), and if your goal is to get people to get out the tissues while still in the theater, good on ya, you achieved your objective. If you want people to actually empathize with the character, so you get butts in seats for repeat showings despite outrageous ticket prices, however, you want to create a character who people can actually identify with. This is why the bean counters are more interested in the second week's gross for a film (and the percentage drop) than the media, who couldn't care less about anything but opening weekend. How many butts came <em>back</em> for a second viewing? Like any other trope, the Magical Negro is a cardboard cutout, a person with little if any personality, a projection of the ideals of the screenwriter rather than a fully fleshed-out character. And like any other cardboard character, we look at them, we pity them... but we don't identify with them. We don't care.Second: for the love of god, Hollywood, you have suffered from this sickness as long as I've known you. In fact, from what I hear from people older than I am, you've suffered from it as long as you've been around. And it's time someone told you about it. It's this habit you have of optioning books, and then hiring screenwriters whose sole purpose, it seems, is to strip out any part of the book that might actually provoke thought. Now, before I launch into this diatribe, I will say right up front I have not yet read the book. I spent the drive home from the cinema listening to my wife detail the differences between book and film, and then went and backed that up with some research. While I understand that books need to be dumbed down for Hollywood for time constraints if nothing else (note: I don't know a single person who would have complained if Jackson's Lord of the Rings adaptations had been three times as long and included, you know, the rest of the story), it's the changes that are made that define whether an adaptation has an agenda or not. I love the way Mark Blankenship puts it, writing at The Critical Condition: "Though it tells roughly the same story as the novel, it makes several small changes that seriously upend the racial balance. Much more than the novel, the movie is a story about white people being awesome and noble." For example, Abilene's final monologue in the film speaks to oh-look-how-empowered-I-am-now!, and without knowing what happens immediately after that, the viewer is inclined to think "hey, you know, she owes a [censored for Amazon consumption] of a lot to Skeeter", rather than "hey, Abilene used this newly-cultivated writing ability to go take Skeeter's old job at the Jackson Journal, which is why Mae Mobley was Abilene's last white child". We go from Abilene being passively grateful to Abilene actively being <em>empowered</em>. It makes me wonder how those who say the movie stuck so close to the book actually find a way to believe that. While we're on the subject of Abilene, stopping her first conversation with Skeeter at the "I drank too much coffee" joke makes for a nice feel-good scene, to be sure. It never gets into the subject which is actually supposed to be at the heart of the movie: <em>why</em> Abilene had seventeen white children--the process of inculcation those white children went through that starts with "you're my real mommy, Abilene!" and ends with Hilly Holbrook (Bryce Dallas Howard), a Klansman in lipstick. That's not something you can simply take out and still have a movie that's functionally the same as the book; it's a <em>main theme</em>. It would be like, for example, taking John W. Campbell's novella "Who Goes There?" and making it into a film where the monster isn't a shapeshifter and there are women in the story. (Oh, wait, Christian Nyby and Howard Hawks did that in 1951 and called it <em>The Thing from Another World</em>. John Carpenter's 1982 adaptation <em>The Thing</em> is much closer to the original source material--and a far superior film.) And I haven't even touched on the whole Rachel debacle, mostly because that's what most critics (and I here use the term in the sense of "people who are pillorying this adaptation") touch on when they're looking at scenes that, in Blankenship's somewhat euphemistic language, "seriously upend the racial balance."I know how I sound here, and I feel kind of guilty about it. I know at least half of you reading this are staring at the screen with a slightly cocked expression thinking "why does a white guy care about this stuff?". For the same reason I care about the fact that Christian Nyby and Howard Hawks changed what is, arguably, the most terrifying monster ever seen in a horror novella (so wonderfully recreated by Rick Baker in the eighties) into James Arness in a suit that makes him look like giant rutabaga. Because these things are in the book, and the reason they are in the book is because the author felt they were important enough to include in the book. Because these changes were made specifically for the purpose of pulling in audiences (and the fact that I feel I have to parenthetically add that I mean <em>white</em> audiences is telling), which brings up concepts of art vs. capital and which one always wins in the end if you put up with the Hollywood machine. But more than either of those things it's because <em>this is our history</em>. This is our culture. And whether you're willing to admit it or not, Hollywood, how the generations below mine conceive of our history and culture in past time periods has a whole [censored for Amazon consumption] of a lot more to do with how you portray it than with what they read in history books, so every time you choose to sanitize some seemingly-niggling piece of detail in order to make something more palatable, you are potentially changing the historical viewpoint of <em>an entire generation of moviegoers</em>. This is doubly distressing when you realize that even in cultures where there is a thriving film industry (Nigeria, India, Turkey, Ghana, New Zealand, France, and England all come to mind), the importation, distribution, and screening of American films, especially high-grossing Hollywood fare, is a billions-of-dollars-a-year business. <em>Billions</em>. And you know how much is in a Ghanian schoolkid's history book about US history? As much as there is in an American kid's schoolbook about the history of Ghana... which means that all those kids overseas, assuming they're not told any different by older relatives who are far more in touch with world events than most Americans of the same age, have no other recourse for figuring out what actually happened.And needless to say, if you do realize all of this and you're still doing it? That's not neglectful. That's evil. That's The Party (a la Orwell) [censored for Amazon consumption]. "We are at war with Eurasia. We have always been at war with Eurasia." becomes "blacks are free in America only because white people fought for their civil rights." And a century from now when there's no one left alive who was actually there, no one left to set the story straight, what happens?Wow. Maybe I went a little overboard when I was doing that research. And it really is a testament to Taylor (who, I just read, is a "longtime friend" of Stockett's, though no details were given) that despite my outrage, which keeps growing the more I think about those "minor" changes, I can still turn around and recommend this movie without hesitation. To reiterate, this cast is outrageously good, and many of them are giving their best performances in years. I can't remember Sissy Spacek, whose role in the film is far too small for her character's irrepressible personality, having been this good in a movie since <em>'night, Mother</em> in 1986. Allison Janney is always a treat. Emma Stone came into her own last year in <em>Easy A</em>, and she does just as well here. Viola Davis, nominated for an Oscar for her work in <em>Doubt</em>, fills the role of Abilene with a warmth and comfort rarely seen on a screen, and Octavia Spencer, who I think has been in every movie that's come out in the past ten years, is a perfect foil for her as trash-talking, hyper-caffeinated Minnie. And I'm just scratching the surface here. It's a [censored for Amazon consumption] of a roster, and it seems to me that everyone involved believed in the film just as passionately as did Taylor; enough, at least, to have all acted their hearts out. And as far as all the behind-the-scenes stuff goes, it's all very well executed, though I doubt anyone's going to be winning awards for, say, sound mixing here. So see it. But I beg you: please think about the process involved in making it after you do. Go out on the web and do the research, or read the book yourself, and then spend some quality time thinking about not just the empirical changes that were made, but the ways in which those changes affect how you think about the characters. Or, far more importantly, how Tate Taylor, who did the adaptation, and Dreamworks, who released the film, <em>wanted</em> you to think about the characters. (How much of the finished film was Taylor's actual screenplay and how much was studio interference is one of those questions to which it's almost impossible to get a good answer, where any film is concerned; even the "director's cut" of any given mainstream movie, unless it's self-released, still goes through the studio system, the MPAA, etc. And, of course, if studio interference happens before shooting, pieces of screenplay may never get filmed.) Using the film as a springboard to think about the Hollywood studio system and the way it sanitizes history is far more useful than using it as "rah rah rah, white people helped the poor [censored for Amazon consumption] out of their misery and now everything's peachy!" propaganda. ***
summary: Warning: I got a little passionate in this review...

reviewText: The Help is the best film I have seen this year.  This film is about the examples of accepted racism in the early sixties, but it is also about the friendship between women. I like the way director Tate Taylor deals with both subjects equally well.There is a very beautiful song included in the movie. It is entitled "The Living Proof". It is performed by R and B singer Mary J. Blige.  This is such a moving song about enduring hard times but still having a sense of dignity about life.  The soundtrack also includes classic songs by Chubby Checker and Frankie Valli, but the new Blige song is definitely the highlight in regards to the music.The performances by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer are excellent.  They are two black maids who both work for white families.  They cook, clean and raise other people's children.  These maids do their jobs do their jobs with such dignity.  I admire these fictional characters.  They seem like real people to me.  These actresses bring the characters of a novel to life on screen.  Emma Stone plays an aspiring writer who documents the experiences of these two women in a book entitled The Help.  Bryce Dallas Howard plays a racist white woman.  Jessica Chastain plays another white female character with a much softer heart. Sissy Spacek gives the movie a humorous element with her performance.  I laughed and cried watching The Help.  The Help is an excellent film.
summary: The Help is the best film I have seen all year.

reviewText: This is a fine film, about a group of women in a dynamic time when many certainties and ways of doing things are coming into question.  The setting is Mississippi, perhaps the most violent Jim Crow state in the Union, composed of many, many layers.  There are the affluent whites, most of whom have no empathy for those not in their narrow world, and "the help", the black women who do most of the chores around the house and are participants but not part of the family.Enter into the mix a feisty young college grad, who has vivid memories of her nanny, played by the amazing Cicely Tyson, and who is accepted by the "good" whites but never quite fit in.  There is a mystery to her disappearance from the family and the young lady, who wants to write for a living, can't get answers from her rigid mother.  She finally get a job at the local paper in the journalistic underclass that writes for a name-brand columnist on rather mundane household issues.  But what she really wants to do is a book on the domestics, who she goes about cultivating.  The nannies are afraid to talk for the record, realistically fearing that they may be lynched or ostracized.  Of course, with the push of an aggressive editor (a wonderfully realistic and manipulative character played by Steenbowgen), she gets their stories as events unfold.  The stories are wonderful.A subplot is a fight she has with one of her old friends, who displays the kind of racism that is in the bones of many southerners - not overt, and fully justified in her mind ("they are different", "separate but equal"), and ultimately cruelly lacking in empathy or understanding.  The writer plays her along, never confronting her, yet working to expose her hypocrisy and narcissism and in the end, almost blackmailing her into silence.Interestingly, the good guys in this are not the best looking.  This is a very fun reversal.  The film also strives to be realistic, without a hint of over-played comedy yet many funny and ironic moments that are very real.  The only relatively weak performance, unfortunately, was the writer; some of her acting did not always ring true to me.The film moved me for many reasons.  I too had a nanny, as my mother was one of the first career women of her generation, and I benefitted greatly from her intelligence and support while growing up.  I loved her, yet also feel I never did enough to thank her.  This brought tears to my eyes.  I also had relatives in the south, some of whom I still consider close family.  Their attitudes to race shocked me, though some of them struggled with it.  The film helped me to reflect on this yet again.
summary: a moving and realistic look into a changing deep south

reviewText: This movie and the book which originally inspired it undoubtedly takes some liberties with explaining race and gender relations.I watched it as a person with disabilities who did grow up with my own restrictions and laws. The book and this film does not deal with disability (except for fleeting references to cancer in Skeeter's mother), but I could certainly relate to the experiences and issues raised in 'The Help'.I give the screenplay kudos for publically explaining that the women did face discrimination and segregation on a regular basis. It realistically portrays the numerous rules and customs which governed the mobility of Abileen and the other domestic workers in 1960's Jackson. Limited mobility translated into difficult and limited life choices.When Skeeter 'really' interviews Aibileen, both are obviously cautious when she goes to the house in the 'Negro' part of town. Having researched State laws then on the books, Skeeter visibly starts to understand how much trouble these interviews could actually cause. It is different than asking a domestic to 'help' answer a newspaper advice column.Because she is not undertaking this assignment lightly, she then wins over the trust of Minny and others who were initially more skeptical of motives for wanting to write about 'their' lives.  They come to trust Skeeter, forming a multi-cultural sisterhood out of the business arrangment.Of course, you would be skeptical too after a life-time of mistreatment, having to clean up for others for inadequate pay. The domestics could not even use the in-house toilets of their employers! And they witnessed the abuse which these 'good' women subject their own families to, refusing to change a child's soiled diaper until their morning arrival.While I'm uneasy how much gennuine 'care' a domestic actually felt towards the children of their employers, arriving at a house and seeing a young child in soiled clothing had to be troubling and frustrating because of inevitably produced health problems. Proving the insanity of racism, the domestics were actually being stereotyped as the 'unclean' ones!Bryce Dallas Howard gives a great performance as the evil Hilly Holbrook. This president of the Jackson Junior League is so interested in collecting canned food for 'poor starving children in Africa'. Holbrook thne ironically chooses to ignore the extreme poverty and violent conditions her own domestic and others routinely face every single day because of Jim Crow Laws. Becoming a domestic was the only kind of work which these women were able to obtain!And then, several neighbors believe that only a 'negress' wrote the book-within-a-movie which eventually gets published from these interviews. The idea that another white person could be interested enough to listen to 'those people' is genuinely unfathomable: Domestics are expected to listen to families as part of their job, but their employers aren't ever expected to recognize their hard work.An exception is Ceila Foote who is herself 'different' in this era. She is recovering from a series of miscarriages and really does need an extra pair of hands as part of her road to recovery. She proactively eats in the kitchen with Minny and provides Minny with the care to escape domestic violence which Hilly and other employers never would. This actually shocks the usually-outspoken Minny. She recognizes that important cultural and social barriers were being broken--wanting them finally broken and actually getting to this point were two very different actions.As much as she needs a job, Minny is intially unsure if Ceila is playing some kind of 'game' with her. Unlike Hilly, the lower-income Celia is less concious of the racial barriers of the era. She and her husband (who actually might have harassed Minny in another screenplay) are sincerely nice to Minny.An obvious strength of this movie and why I was interested in seeing it was that the civil rights movement is used as backdrop. It shows everyday people actually working to change their difficult conditions during the era, something which should still resonate in our era of Occupy Wall Street. The women weren't just passively accepting the discrimination and segregation which was very much a part of their daily lives. And they are also very much concious of 'national' events such as President Kennedy's and Medgar Evers's assassination, without themselves being these 'famous' names.Skeeter did help the domestics initially tell their stories. But Aibileen and her colleagues are the only ones who were then capable of taking the received book royalty money and deciding what to do with it. They helped each other and themselves make a better life.My only real complaint is the menu design--which looks like it was pirated. The movie itself is awesome.
summary: Help Yourself To a Good Movie

reviewText: None of what I kept fearing would show actually did--in this type of film, the filmmakers so often throw in melodrama and unbelievable scenes just to manipulate the viewers' emotions.  For example, I kept fearing that a horrible reprisal was in store for us after the book was published, one that would stretch the limits of believability.  It never did, and that's a good thing.This is a very well-told story that is extremely well acted with often subtle performances that convey a beautiful story of risk, cooperation, hope, and compassion.  My only reason for not giving it five stars, though, is the editing--there are some scenes that drag, and they go slow for really no obvious reason.  This film easily could have been 20 minutes shorter with no loss.  It just doesn't feel tight.  And while that's certainly not a fatal flaw--I still loved the movie--it is something that detracts from the overall experience.

I laughed, cried, and got mad during this movie because it felt like home.

reviewText: Reading the book first would definitely be my advice before viewing this movie because with the movie it seems to focus solely on racial tensions and that's honestly not what the book is about. The book is truly about treating people with respect and kindness. There's one line towards the end of the book that sums it up perfectly on page 492 of the book, "Wasn't that the point of the book? For women to realize, We are just two people. Not that much separates us. Not nearly as much as I'd thought." The movie should have concentrated more on the relationships between the women instead of nearly eclipsing that with the circumstances during those times. The circumstances were more of the background of the story, it was the women's attitudes towards one another, their bond, their courage--all of that made the book what it was. The movie merely glossed over those and made the connection between the women nearly obsolete.I don't expect the writers and directors of films to please everyone with the outcome, but sometimes, like with this movie, it seems they barely even try. When movies like "It's A Wonderful Life" was being adapted into films, script after script was rejected and rewritten before they came up with something satisfactory. Now? It seems they accept the first one simply because it has a beginning and an end and then idiots pat them on the back. All this director did was pull a bunch of lines from the book and arranged them. Not only that, he BUTCHERED some of the secondary plots. I'll give you examples:1) Octavia Spencer WAS Minny Jackson and Jessica Chastain WAS the Miss Celia I'd pictured. They are both incredible actresses. But their parts were so limited, I felt as though their characters were cheated. The scene when Celia miscarried could have been more intense, so could her meeting with Johnny, but the thing that pissed me off the most was that I believe one of the most VITAL parts of the book were left out of the film. There was a part in the book where Minny tries to protect herself and Celia from a crazy man that came onto their property and in the end Celia is the one that ends up fending the attacker from Minny, basically saving her help's life.  It also showed their true relationship--that Celia FELT something for Minny. The part when a doctor had to be called when Celia lost her baby and was hemorrhaging badly and Minny was the one who called him was the actual proof that Minny had once saved her life. Yet, there was no such scene in the movie.2) Why bother saying that Minny even had an abusive husband in the first place if the idiot writer was just going to act like sitting at a table seeing some food gave her enough courage to leave him? Huh? Really? His point was she'd taught her white boss how to cook so somehow that translated into her taking all of her kids and leaving a man she's been with it seems for probably 20 years and put up with his crap all that time and all of a sudden it's only now sitting at a table looking at good food is going to give her the gumption to go. The sad part is, people don't even scream that this is insulting the audiences' intelligence--everybody seems to be going along with everything this movie is and not saying a thing no matter how ridiculous this film made it seem.3) Constantine's story in the movie makes little to no sense at all. There are so many vital elements left out of that story it's a shame; and the parts that the writer of the movie put in are simply an embarrassment. The movie just made Constantine's daughter look haughty and disrespectful and that's not how she should've been depicted at all. Lulabelle was Constantine's daughter's name in the book, but apparently in the screen adaption, "Rachel" was somehow more appropriate *shrugs* (As if Mae Mobley didn't sound like a ridiculous name? If you're going to keep a baby named Mae Mobley, why not keep Lulabelle?), but she was just as much a victim of circumstance as any of the other women and she had a reason to be angry as well. She didn't just barge into Charlotte's house for no reason at all. Charlotte's role in the movie was also changed--she was vicious and vindictive when it came to Constantine between the pages of the book and Charlotte really did do her wrong, but we get none of that in the movie.I'm glad I read the book first because I'm not sure what my reaction would've been had I seen this watered down movie version. Knowing the back story for the characters and their situations was its only saving grace for me. Was the majority of the acting terrific? Yes, it was. Was it shot beautifully? Indeed, it was. Was the script poorly written? I must say, it was.The real story, the one you find between the pages of the book in which this movie was based on, is ugly and powerful and wonderful all at the same time. It'll make you laugh and cry--and this is coming from someone who didn't even want to read the book at first. The book is about women and their friendships with one another, women and their relationships with their children, women and their relationships with the help they have in their household, women and their relationships with themselves. Race comes secondary when it comes to the real story found in the book. The movie was more flashy than anything with Lafayette from True Blood (don't get me wrong, I love Nelsan Ellis, and he's amazingly talented, but it's almost gimmicky to have certain actors in films nowadays and his part kind of felt that way even though he was flawless). Also the character given to Leslie Jordan (known for his role on Will and Grace as Beverley Leslie) came off that way as well--gimmicky (esp with the cartwheel he did at the Benefit, I believe it was). That character was meant to be a chunky hard around the edges kinda guy, but he was funny.Most people are screaming that this movie is sooooo great, and it really isn't. It's mediocre at best. The book is truly wonderful.

reviewText: Writer-director Tate Taylor's adaptation of Kathryn Stockett's novel suffers from an erratic tone and overlength - deleting crucial details yet taking forever to get started. Despite its flaws, "The Help" (2011) is redeemed by a powerful ensemble cast. Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer are a revelation - deserving of all the praise and awards. However, "The Help" would have benefited from a stronger directorial hand. Taylor's cinematic inexperience prevents this social drama from reaching greatness - regrettably lacking the admirable courage of Aibileen and Minnie.

reviewText: After initially being rejected by over 60 publishers, Kathryn Stockett's The Help was finally published in February of 2009.  Since that time, this incendiary tale of the small and not-so-small abuses suffered by black housekeepers in the 1960s has gone on to sell over 5 million copies, as it spent over 100 weeks on the New York Times Best Seller List.Set in Jackson Mississippi during the early 1960s, the film tells the story of Skeeter Phelan, a young southern society girl who longs to become a writer.  When Skeeter's beloved housekeeper is suddenly dismissed under pressure from her mother's society friends, Skeeter is concerned and begins to document the stories of her friend's domestic workers.  As one black woman after the next courageously steps forward to tell her tale, the book begins to take shape, and a town will be forever changed.My reaction to this film is somewhat hard to pin down.  On the one hand, I am always drawn to stories where someone has the courage to swim against the stream, and in so doing, brings justice to those that have been oppressed.  These are important stories to tell, for they remind us that change does not often begin in the corridors of power.  Change begins when insignificant people dare to speak prophetic truth into a world that is desperate for truth to be spoken.On the other hand, movies like this sometimes feel "safe" because they are told from a distance.  Fifty years after the dawn of the Civil Rights Movement in the United States, how many people would genuinely argue that black people did not suffer under white society?  So it's easy to root for the heroes, demonize the villains, and feel as if  "the job is done."  And there is a danger in that feeling as if the "job is done" because we are encouraged to believe that we can sit safely in the comforts of our own homes.How much more exciting would it be to see a story set in the contemporary world in which someone dared to tell the story of the plight of modern day Native Americans or modern day slaves?  How much more compelling would it be to have to face our own complicit guilt in avoiding the issues and burying our collective heads in the sand?In the end, I strongly recommend viewing The Help, and dare you not cheer as Hilly eats the pie.Further reviews can be found at bloodstainedink.wordpress.com.
summary: The Help: A One-Minute Film Review

reviewText: I agree with the other reviewers who say this film is primarily a feel-good white liberal take on racial segregation, the worn-out formula of painting all whites with traditional values as slave-owning racists who deserve whatever they get, long-suffering blacks who can do no wrong, and the one "good" white person who saves the blacks from the other, evil whites.  Hollywood has been making variations of the same tired movie for half a century now.  It's the classical neo-liberal trade-off -- you want to simultaneously vilify whites as a race and get whites to buy tickets, so you show one of them championing the Hollywood version of the black cause.  It's both insulting to whites, the vast majority of whom have nothing to answer for, and insulting to blacks, because it paints them as being unable to succeed without liberal whites to save them.As with most made-for-Oscars liberal agit-prop pieces, the acting is quite good and the fit-and-finish are above reproach.  Hollywood's alien elite typically pulls out all the stops for these template movies, and this is no exception.  Leukophobes and self-styled liberal saviors of black America will love it.  Proud blacks will resent it, and proud whites should call it out for being the white-bashing, vapid trash that it is.

reviewText: The Help in its idea alone is perhaps one of the most original ideas to come along in recent film history. I mean to say, a movie based on the hardships and life of African-American female housemaids during the 1960s? Not only that, but their Caucasian house bosses and all the social borders, stigmas, prejadices and love that intermix. The Help stars a stellar cast who some by no surprise are up for 2011 Oscar nominations, not to also mention the film's Oscar nomination for Best Picture of the Year. A very well-deserved achievement.The film takes us into a fairly well off suburban neighborhood during the 1960s, when the first few ripples of the civil rights movement was beginning, and how it affected the always strict relationship that these Caucasian homeowners had with their maids. The film stars the up and coming Emma Stone as Skeeter, the single, headstrong, and brave writer who is on a mission to write a book detailing all the stories of the African-American maids around the neighborhood, to create a piece from their own point of view. This of course causes much controversy as not only are the maids hesitant to take part, as doing so may cause them to get into heaps of trouble, as well as risk their ability to ever be hired again, but also frightens her Caucasion relatives and friends, as writing such a book would risk bringing a dramatic change to their comfortable and stable domineering relationship with their housemaids. Viola Davis and Octavian Spencer play 2 other housemaids with their own house bosses - the spoiled, trite and cruel 'Hilly' played by Bryce Dallas Howard and 'Celia' played entertainingly and adorably well as the bubbly and joyful yet strong new-girl-on-the-block by Jessica Chastain. Viola and Octavian put on Oscar-nominated performances and truly steal the show, bringing us humor, compassion and stellar wit to their characters. Their Oscar nominations are extremely well-deserved. Veteran actress Allison Janney plays the insecure and emotionally struggling mother of Skeeter, who is most on the fence about her firing of her oldest housemaid, struggling with her love and compassion vs. her social status.The film brings shows us all the troubles and tribulations of the housemaids (there are others besides Viola and Octavia in more minor roles with their own homeowners played well by other supporting cast members), but not only that, the film also displays the tension between the Caucasian homeowners themselves, thus showing us that even though they are at a socially sigmatic position as the white "slave-drivers," they do not embrace such a status, yet struggle to show as much compassion to their housemaids meanwhile maintaining the authority society tells them they must have.Our star, Skeer (Emma Stone) encounters tension from both sides, as well as from her mother who can't stand to see her single anymore. She eventually begins her work with writing her book and things flair up from there.What makes this such an incredible film is its love for the characters. Dialogue throughout is extremely precise in terms of dialect and tone, not to also mention interesting and very well written. The amazing performances only highlight this aspect, and we grow to love the characters through all their struggles. The most vital being 2 in particular - Skeeter's frustration with her family as the firing of their oldest maid to her is akin to the firing of her own mother (as the housemaid for the most part RAISED Skeeter herself), and Aibileen's (Viola Davis) struggles with overcoming the death of her son and all the scars that has left her in terms of virtually all Caucasians; she walks the line between humility and deeply embedded anger, meanwhile always walking in a state of ongoing sadness.The drama with the homeowner side of things eventually grows as more of the comedic relief throughout the film, but the audience will be much more interested in how the housemaids overcome their side of things. If there was any flaw, I felt that towards the end, while the struggles with the White homeowner's relationships build to be more entertaining and not so much heartfelt, things felt a bit forced by the end, yet it never goes so far as to step over the line of unbelievability.The pacing and editing in the film is spot-on, and even with a running time of 2 hours and 20 minutes, you'll feel the need to watch this one again and again, simply because the setting, pacing and dialogue in the film is simply either too entertaining, passionate and soothing as a whole.Lastly, for all the guys out there worried about their girlfriends or wives dragging them to see this one, please keep in mind that this is NOT a "Chick Flick." Far from it. No, this is a realistic fiction (although based on the author's true life story) film about the struggles of people trying to live through an era where they were being both pushed down, intimidated, yet freed from years and years of segregation. Instead of this being a film displaying the civil rights movement as a whole (as in the film Malcom X), this scopes in on one suburban neighborhood, showing us what everyday people did to deal with the societal changes, and all the inner struggles as they now had to find a line between tradition and societal progression.Overall a fantastic, heartwarming, gritty, and truely moving film.
summary: A Stellar Achievement For a "Lesser Known" People in History
